topic.shortdesc: Take backups to a backup repository.

section.title: Description
section.p: When this command is run, it reads the backup configuration from the specified backup repository, and takes a backup. All backups in a backup repository are performed incrementally so that each backup resumes from where the previous backup left off. Using an incremental backup strategy significantly reduces the amount of data that must be backed up and reduces the amount of time a backup takes.

Each backup creates a new folder in the backup repository. This folder name will be set to the RFC 3339 timestamp that corresponds to the time that the backup started. All backup data will be written to this folder.

If the backup fails for any reason before completion, it can be resumed from where the backup left off or restarted from the previous successful backup. If the backup is resumed, the backup client will attempt to complete the unfinished backup. If the backup is restarted from the last successful backup, the incomplete backup will be removed and a new backup created.

section.title: Options
section.p:
The following are the command options:
cluster options
Option Description
--dir /[directory name] Name of the backup directory.
--name REPOSITORY-NAME Take a backup from the named backup repository.
--host HOSTNAME Name of the host from where the backup is taken.
--username USERNAME Login of the administrator who is taking the backup.
--password PASSWORD Password of the administrator who is taking the backup.

section.title: Examples
section.p: Take a backup: ./backup cluster --dir /tmp/backups --name travel --host couchbase://localhost \ --username Administrator --password password
Attempt to resume a failed backup: ./backup cluster --dir /tmp/backups --name travel --host couchbase://localhost \ --username Administrator --password password --purge

Remove a failed backup and start a new one from the last successful backup: ./backup cluster --dir /tmp/backups --name travel --host couchbase://localhost \ --username Administrator --password password --purge
